bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Henry Rose Carter, July 7, 1924

div1.p: White writes that he is willing to accept Carter's conclusion regarding the origin of yellow fever. He discusses the situation in Brazil and Africa in regards to yellow fever.

JOSEPH H. WHITE, M.D., DIRECTOR
7th. July, 1924.
Dear Doctor,
div1.p:
Your letter dated simply June came this week and I
am very glad to hear from you and to know that you have been
able to finish your writing.

I have not yet received the carbon which you state
Dr. Russell would send me, but I suppose I shall get it by next
mail, and I also suppose you have already ascertained the
address of Guiteras, if not I can tell you that it is, ‘Benevides,
Mantanzas, Cuba.’

I also knew of your conclusion regarding the African
origin of Yellow Fever, and because it explained so many things
otherwise inexplicable, I was from the very first, willing to
accept it as the truth, however, I will write more fully about
that after I have read your paper.

My work is going along as well as could be expected,
and despite the fact that I find here, as I have always found
and always expect to find in every new field, certain new pro-
blems not encountered before, and which must be met and handled
on their own merits.

I don't quite understand your remark about many people
on the coast being immune as such immunity is the rule in all
endemic countries that I have ever seen and along with that
immunity in the coastal cities, there is an immense amount of
contact with the high country in the rear which furnishes a cons-
tant supply of non-immunes.

I feel a little more confortable about West Africa. The
first reason being that up to the present time all the ships
coming from West Africa are very, very slow steamers. There has
been only one sailing vessel in 18 months, so I am informed, and
that was a yacht. There is more contact going from Brazil to
Africa - many times more - but that does not hurt. The second
reason is that all the contact is with Dakar which at least is
apparently clean at the present time, while, from all the infor-
mation I have been able to get, the bulk of the infection is in
the Bight of Benin, certainly at Lagos and Accra, and most pro-
bably in the big mud walled native city of Abeokuta of 150,000
people, about 150 miles from the coast.

Coming back to personal matters, the family like Brazil
and naturally I am very glad to have them for I am getting old,
and I miss home more and more all the time, and of course my wife
and two daughters make home wherever they are.

You refer to Dr. Goeldi of Pará and ask me to thank him
for the extract from his book, but I shall not be able to comply
File Y. F.
White
Dr. H.R. Carter
- 3 -
7th. July, 1924.
with your request for Goeldi has gone to his “long Home”, and if
the Priests and Prophets of our faith know what they are talking
about, Goeldi now knows much more about Yellow Fever than you or
I. You speak of being near the end, and I sometimes think that
I also am nearing the end, and I doubt if I shall undertake ano-
ther task as strenuous as have been the Mexican and Brazilian
campaigns, though I really would like to initiate the work in
Africa for many reasons, the principal of these being that I have
gathered a great deal of data which I have sifted very carefully,
that I have spent many sleepless nights in what old Dr. Jimmie
Reid used to call “study without books”, and that I believe that
I have a better and deeper conception of the African problem than
anybody else now engaged in the work. Hence it is logical that
I should want to inaugurate the campaign, but I do not want to
complete it, or at least I could not.
All the family join me in sending love to you and all.

Very sincerely yours, J. H. White Dr. H.R. Carter,
